content: Ecuadorean President Rafael Correa ordered a U.S. Embassy official expelled on Saturday after accusing him of interfering in the country’s affairs, a move that will test ties with Washington. Correa, a leftist, has generally kept good relations with the United States as his socialist allies in Bolivia and Venezuela often clash with Washington over what they say is U.S. "imperialism" in Latin America. "Foreign minister, give this gentleman 48 hours to pack up his suitcases and get out of the country," Correa said during his weekly media address. "We’re not going to let anyone treat us as if we were a colony here." He said U.S. official Armando Astorga had abruptly ended a financing agreement with local police after authorities rejected his attempts to handpick officers he wanted to manage the U.S. aid projects. "Mr. Astorga, keep your dirty money. We don’t need it. We have dignity in this country," Correa said. "Ecuador doesn’t need charity from anyone." The U.S. State Department was aware of the announcement and checking into it, spokesman Fred Lash said. more here: "http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_55540.shtml" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: ] Holy crap. Another dictator ob will give a 'high five' too one day--maybe even a hug! last time I looked, Correa won election by >10% in 06 and is poised to win again in 09 by a bigger margin. If our foriegn policy will continue to be "building democracy" in other parts of the world, we're gonna have to start payin' attention to the distinction. reading the article, it looks like micromanaging on our part. soveriegnty is not a function of GNP or military might.

Imo, we really can't afford to be providing foreign aid to anyone right now, (not with The One in office, "H"e's already indebted our grandchildren with "H"is domestic spending), least of all to a worthless, (and apparently ungrateful), little $hithole like Ecuador. I say we do as he asks and leave, taking our money with us. El Presidente Correa or one of his proxies would be begging us, (and our money), to return within 6 months.

I say we do as he asks and leave, taking our money with us. El Presidente Correa or one of his proxies would be begging us, (and our money), to return within 6 months. Ecuador's economy may not be big, but for an emerging nation their future looks bright. HUGE natural resources and a dead-nuts even balance of trade. the whole reason Correa got in was cause the last guy wanted to dollarize the economy, something most Ecuadorians are glad never happened. as far as "providing foriegn aid to anyone" right now, it's probably a good time to lookit all the emerging nations and "democracies" we're funding these days (2006 figures): 2006 foriegn aid in millions Israel Economic Aid (ESF) 240 Military Aid (FMF) 2,280 Israel Total 2,520 Egypt Economic Aid (ESF) 495 Military Aid FMF) 1,300 Egypt Total 1,795 . Columbia 558 Jordan 461 Pakistan 698 Peru 133 Indonesia 158 Kenya 213 Bolivia 122 Ukraine 115 India 94 Haiti 163 Russia 52 Ethiopia 145 West Bank/ Gaza 150 Liberia 89 Bangladesh 49 Bosnia 51

content: "Ola senor, you would like to buy my seester? Cheep? Out of my way, vermin. I'm here to see the Ambassador! I can get heem for you, too, senor. Eet jus cost you a leetle extra." - Cheech & Chong, Vaughn Meader or somebody. Is all American 'foreign aid' in the form of police and military t & l? What a joke - can't even give it away right.
